Package com.rb.nonbiz.functional

Class SimpleStepFunctionRBNumericFunctionBuilder<X extends java.lang.Number,​Y extends RBNumeric<? super Y>>

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.functional.SimpleStepFunctionRBNumericFunctionBuilder<X,​Y>
All Implemented Interfaces:
RBBuilder<RBNumericFunction<X,​Y>>
public class SimpleStepFunctionRBNumericFunctionBuilder<X extends java.lang.Number,​Y extends RBNumeric<? super Y>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements RBBuilder<RBNumericFunction<X,​Y>>
This lets you build a simple step function with one y-value Y0 below a specified X0, and another value Y1 at X0 or above:
  • y = y0 for x < x0.
  • y = y1 for x ≥ x0.

In ASCII art: 

               (x0, y1)
                *-------------->
                |
                |
                |
 ---------------O
             (x0, y0)

Note that the lower point is denoted with an open circle ("O") while the upper point uses an asterix ("*"). This denotes that for x = x0, y = y1, not y0.

This class can also model the opposite choice for y when x = x0:

  • y = y0 for x ≤ x0.
  • y = y1 for x > x0. 
               (x0, y0)
 ---------------*
                |
                |
                |
                O---------------
             (x0, y1)

This is called "simple" because there is only a single step. In general, a step function could have many regions of constant y-values {Y0, Y1, Y2, ...} separated by x-values {X0, X1, X2 ....}.

This class could be named "SingleStepFunction...", except that that might imply that it holds a single many-valued step function. Our usual convention is that a "Single..." class is a single instance held in a higher-level container class that holds many "Singles".
